projects.name: Pinecraft
projects.description: An automated Minecraft Java server installer for Raspberry Pi, maintained at the cat5tv/Pinecraft GitHub repository.

sections.title: Overview
sections.content:
**Pinecraft** is an automated Minecraft Java server installer for Raspberry Pi, maintained at the [cat5tv/Pinecraft GitHub repository](https://github.com/cat5tv/Pinecraft).

This guide is designed for beginner to intermediate Raspberry Pi users. No prior Pi experience is assumed, but commands are shown exactly as they should be entered.

Follow each step in order. Do not skip steps or use alternative methods.

sections.title: Estimated Time
sections.content: **30–60 minutes** depending on download speeds and hardware. The process involves flashing an OS, configuration, and server setup.

sections.title: Hardware Requirements
sections.content:
### Required Hardware

- **Raspberry Pi 4** (4GB or 8GB RAM recommended)
- MicroSD card (32GB+ Class 10/UHS-1) or USB drive
- Official Raspberry Pi power supply (3A USB-C)
- Computer for setup (Windows, macOS, or Linux)

### Optional Hardware

- Heatsink and fan for cooling
- External SSD for improved performance
- Case with ventilation

sections.title: Important Note
sections.content: Do **not** use a Raspberry Pi Zero or older Pi models. Pinecraft requires a **Raspberry Pi 4** for adequate performance. Minecraft servers are memory and CPU intensive.

sections.title: Step 1: Install Raspberry Pi Imager
sections.content:
**Raspberry Pi Imager** is the official tool for flashing operating system images to SD cards and USB drives. It is required to install Raspberry Pi OS on your storage device.

Download Raspberry Pi Imager from the official website:

[https://www.raspberrypi.com/software/](https://www.raspberrypi.com/software/)

Raspberry Pi Imager is available for **Windows**, **macOS**, and **Linux**. Download and install the version for your operating system.

sections.title: Step 2: Flash Raspberry Pi OS
sections.content:
**Open Raspberry Pi Imager** - Launch the application you installed in the previous step.
---
**Click Choose Device** - Select your Raspberry Pi model from the list.
---
**Click Choose OS** - Navigate to **Other** and select **Raspberry Pi OS Lite (64-bit)**.
---
**Click Choose Storage** - Select your target SD card or USB drive.
---
**Click Next** - You will be prompted to configure settings.
---
**Open Advanced Settings** - Configure the following: **Wi-Fi** (enter your SSID and password), **Username and password** (create your login credentials), **Enable Raspberry Pi Connect** (for remote access).
---
**Apply Settings** - Confirm and begin flashing the image to your storage device.
---
**Safely Eject** - When flashing is complete, safely eject the drive from your computer.

sections.title: Why Lite 64-bit?
sections.content: We use **Raspberry Pi OS Lite (64-bit)** because it has no desktop environment, freeing up RAM and CPU for the Minecraft server. The 64-bit version provides better Java performance.

sections.title: Step 3: First Boot & Remote Access
sections.content:
**Insert the flashed drive** - Insert the SD card or USB drive into your Raspberry Pi.
---
**Power on the Raspberry Pi** - Connect the power supply. The Pi will boot automatically.
---
**Open Raspberry Pi Connect** - From another computer, open your web browser and go to: [https://connect.raspberrypi.com](https://connect.raspberrypi.com)
---
**Sign in and connect** - Sign in with your Raspberry Pi account and connect to your Pi remotely.

sections.title: Step 4: Initial Raspberry Pi Configuration
sections.content:
# Open Raspberry Pi Configuration
sudo raspi-config

# Navigate to: Advanced Options → Expand Filesystem
# Then exit raspi-config

# Update the System
sudo apt update
sudo apt upgrade -y

# Install Git
sudo apt install git -y

# Reboot
sudo reboot

sections.title: Configuration Steps
sections.content:
In raspi-config, navigate to:

1. **Advanced Options**
2. **Expand Filesystem**
3. Exit raspi-config

After the reboot, reconnect via Raspberry Pi Connect to continue.

sections.title: Step 5: Download Pinecraft
sections.content:
# Clone the Pinecraft repository
git clone https://github.com/cat5tv/Pinecraft.git

# Enter the Pinecraft directory
cd Pinecraft

sections.title: GitHub Repository
sections.content: Pinecraft GitHub|https://github.com/cat5tv/Pinecraft|Official repository with source code and documentation

sections.title: Step 6: Run the Pinecraft Installer
sections.content:
# Run the installer with sudo
sudo ./install

sections.title: Installation Flow
sections.content:
**Click OK** - When the welcome screen appears, click OK to continue.
---
**Click OK again** - Acknowledge the information prompt.
---
**Select installation location** - Choose **Main / Home directory** for the installation.
---
**Choose Minecraft version** - Select your preferred Minecraft server version.
---
**Enter world seed** - Provide a seed or leave blank for random generation.
---
**Select game mode** - Choose Survival, Creative, or Adventure mode.
---
**Confirm RAM overclocking** - Confirm when prompted about memory settings.
---
**Wait for installation** - The installer handles all dependencies automatically.

sections.title: Step 7: Checking Server Status
sections.content:
**Important:** Only these two commands are valid with the init.d script:

`/etc/init.d/pinecraft status` - Check if the server is running

`/etc/init.d/pinecraft stop` - Stop the server

**There is no start or restart command in init.d.** Server control is handled differently (see next section).

sections.title: Step 8: Server Control Commands
sections.content:
Start Server|Navigate to your Minecraft folder and run `./server` to start the server.
---
Restart Server|Run `./restart` from within the Minecraft directory to restart.
---
Stop Server|Use `/etc/init.d/pinecraft stop` to gracefully shut down the server.
---
Check Status|Use `/etc/init.d/pinecraft status` to verify if the server is running.

sections.title: Step 9: Updating PaperMC
sections.content:
**Download the latest Paper JAR** - Go to [https://papermc.io/downloads](https://papermc.io/downloads) and download the latest Paper JAR file.
---
**Navigate to the Minecraft directory** - Open the Minecraft folder created by Pinecraft.
---
**Delete the existing JAR** - Delete the file named `Minecraft.jar`.
---
**Rename the downloaded file** - Rename the new Paper JAR file you downloaded to `Minecraft.jar`.
---
**Restart the server** - Run `./restart` to start the server with the updated Paper version.

sections.title: Step 10: Installing Plugins
sections.content:
**Stop the server** - Run `/etc/init.d/pinecraft stop` to shut down the server.
---
**Copy plugin files** - Copy the plugin `.jar` files from your computer.
---
**Paste into plugins folder** - Paste the files into the `plugins` folder inside the Minecraft directory.
---
**Restart the server** - Run `./restart` to start the server with the new plugins loaded.

sections.title: Plugin Resources
sections.content:
SpigotMC Resources|https://www.spigotmc.org/resources/|Thousands of free and premium plugins
Hangar (PaperMC)|https://hangar.papermc.io/|Official Paper plugin repository
Modrinth|https://modrinth.com/plugins|Modern plugin and mod platform

sections.title: Networking Guide
sections.content:
### Local Network Connection

For players on the same network, use your Pi's local IP address. Find it with:

```bash
hostname -I
```

In Minecraft: **Multiplayer** → **Direct Connect** → Enter the local IP.

### Remote Connection

For players outside your network:

1. Find your public IP: `curl ifconfig.me`
2. Forward TCP port **25565** in your router settings
3. Share your public IP with players

sections.title: Security Warning
sections.content:
Opening your server to the internet exposes it to potential attacks. Always:

- Enable whitelist in `server.properties`: set `white-list=true`
- Only add trusted players to your whitelist
- Keep your server software updated
- Consider using a firewall

sections.title: Troubleshooting
sections.content:
Server Won't Start|Check logs for startup errors and diagnostics|tail -f /var/log/pinecraft.log
---
Connection Issues|Verify server is running and network is properly configured. LAN: Confirm same network. Remote: Check port 25565 is forwarded to Pi's local IP.
---
Check Disk Space|Low storage can cause crashes and world corruption|df -h
---
Performance Issues|Reduce server load for smoother gameplay. Lower `view-distance` in `server.properties`. Limit max players. Use Paper for optimizations.
---
Java Errors|Ensure correct Java version is installed|java -version
---
Get Help|Community support for advanced issues. Visit [Pinecraft GitHub Issues](https://github.com/cat5TV/pinecraft/issues)

sections.title: Congratulations!
sections.content: You now have a fully functional Minecraft Java server running on your Raspberry Pi! Invite your friends, explore, build, and have fun. Remember to back up your world files regularly.

projects.name: P4wnP1
projects.description: Highly customizable USB attack platform for Raspberry Pi Zero and Zero W.

sections.title: Overview
sections.content:
P4wnP1 is an open-source, highly customizable USB attack platform for the Raspberry Pi Zero and Zero W. It enables HID attacks, network attacks, and more, all from a tiny, affordable device.

[View the official GitHub repository](https://github.com/RoganDawes/P4wnP1)

sections.title: Estimated Time
sections.content: **15–30 minutes** (including downloads and flashing)

sections.title: Prerequisites
sections.content:
Required Hardware|Raspberry Pi Zero or Zero W, MicroSD card (8GB+ recommended), Micro USB cable (data & power capable), Computer (Windows, macOS, or Linux)
---
Optional Hardware|USB OTG adapter for additional devices, Compact case for portability

sections.title: Installation Guide
sections.content:
**Download Image** - Get the latest P4wnP1 A.L.O.A. image from [GitHub Releases](https://github.com/RoganDawes/P4wnP1/releases)
---
**Flash to SD Card** - Use balenaEtcher to write the image to your microSD card. [Get balenaEtcher](https://www.balena.io/etcher/)
---
**Insert & Connect** - Insert the SD card into Pi Zero. Connect via USB data port (not power-only).
---
**Wait for Boot** - The Pi will boot and appear as a network/HID device on your computer.
---
**Login** - Default credentials: Username: `pi`, Password: `raspberry`
---
**Access Web UI** - Open browser and navigate to the P4wnP1 web interface for configuration.

sections.title: Resources
sections.content:
GitHub Repo|https://github.com/RoganDawes/P4wnP1|Source code, issues, and releases
Wiki & Docs|https://github.com/RoganDawes/P4wnP1/wiki|Payloads, customizations, and advanced features
balenaEtcher|https://www.balena.io/etcher/|Cross-platform SD card flasher tool
